That were convolved within this thrifty room.
Here, stalks me by a proud, and spangled sir,
That looks three handfuls higher than his foretop;
Savours himself alone, is only kind
And loving to himself: one that will speak
More dark, and doubtful than six oracles;
Salutes a friend, as if he had a stitch,
is his own chronicle, and scarce can eat
For registering himself: is waited on
By mimiques, jesters, panders, parasites,
And other such like prodigies of men.
He passed, appears some mincing marmoset
Made all of clothes, and face; his limbs so set
As if they had some voluntary act
Without man's motion, and must move just so
In spite of their creation: one that weighs
His breath between his teeth, and dares not smile
Beyond a point, for fear t'unstarch his look;
Hath travelled to make legs, and seen the cringe
Of several courts, and courtiers; knows the time
Of giving titles, and of taking walls;
Hath read court-common-places; made them his:
Studied the grammar of state, and all the rules
Each formal usher in that politic school,
Can teach a man. A third comes giving nods
To his repenting creditors, protests
To weeping suitors, takes the coming gold
Of insolent, and base ambition,
That hourly rubs his dry, and itchy palms:
Which gripped, like burning coals, he hurls away
Into the laps of bawds, and buffoons mouths.
With him there meets some subtle Proteus, one
Can change, and vary with all forms he sees;
Be any thing but honest; serves the time;
Hovers betwixt two factions, and explores
The drifts of both; which (With cross face) he bears
To the divided heads, and is received
With mutual grace of either: one that dares
Do deeds worthy the hurdle, or the wheel,
To be thought somebody ; and is (In sooth)
Such as the satirist points truly forth,
That only to his crimes owes all his worth.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You tell us wonders, Crites.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: This is nothing.
There stands a neophyte glazing of his face,
Pruning his clothes, perfuming of his hair,
Against his idol enters; and repeats
(Like an unperfect prologue, at third music)
His part of speeches, and confederate jests,
In passion to himself. Another swears
His scene of courtship over; bids, believe him,
Twenty times, ere they will; anon, doth seem
as he would kiss away his hand in kindness;
Then walks of melancholic, and stands wreathed,
As he were pinned up to the arras, thus.
A third is most in action, swims, and frisks,
Plays with his mistress paps, salutes her pumps,
Adores her hems, her skirts, her knots, her curls,
Will spend his patrimony for a garter,
Or the least feather in her bounteous fan.
A fourth, he only comes in for a mute:
Divides the act with a dumb show, and exit.
Then must the ladies laugh, straight comes their scene,
A sixth times worse confusion than the rest.
Where you shall hear one talk of this man's eye;
Another, of his lip; a third, his nose;
A fourth commend his leg; a fifth his foot;
A sixth his hand; and every one a limb:
That you would think the poor distorted gallant
Must there expire. Then fall they in discourse
Of tires, and fashions, how they must take place,
Where they may kiss, and whom, when to sit down,
And with what grace to rise; if they salute,
What curtsy they must use: such cobweb stuff,
As would enforce the commonest sense abhor
Th' arachnean workers.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Patience, gentle Crites.
This knot of spiders will be soon dissolved,
And all their webs swept out of Cynthia's court,
When once her glorious deity appears,
And but presents itself in her full light:
Till when, go in, and spend your hours with us
Your honoured friends, time, and Phronesis,
In contemplation of our goddess name.
Think on some sweet, and choice invention, now,
Worthy her serious, and illustrious eyes,
That from the merit of it we may take
Desired occasion to prefer your worth,
And make your service known to Cynthia.
It is the pride of Arete to grace
Her studious lovers; and (In scorn of time,
Envy, and ignorance) to lift their state
Above a vulgar height. True happiness
Consists not in the multitude of friends,
But in the worth, and choice. Nor would I have
Virtue a popular regard pursue:
Let them be good that love me, though but few.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: I kiss thy hands, divinest Arete,
And vow myself to thee, and Cynthia.

sp.p: A little more forward: so, sir. Now go in, discloak yourself, and come forth. Taylor, bestow thy absence upon us; and be not prodigal of this secret, but to a dear customer. 'tis well intend, sir. Stay, you come on too fast; your pace is too impetuous. Imagine this to be the palace of your pleasure, or place, where your lady is pleased to be seen. First, you present yourself, thus: and spying her, you fall off, and walk some two turns; in which time, it is to be supposed, your passion hath sufficiently whited your face: then (Stifling a sigh or two, and closing your lips) with a trembling boldness, and bold terror, you advance yourself forward. Prove thus much, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Yes, sir, (Pray Jove I can light on it) here, I come in, you say, and present myself?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: And then I spy her, and walk off?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Now, sir, I stifle, and advance forward?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Trembling.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Yes, sir, trembling: I shall do it better when I come to it. And what must I speak now?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Marry, you shall say: dear beauty, or, sweet honour (Or by what other title you please to remember her) methinks you are melancholy. This is, if she be alone now, and discompanied.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Well, sir, I'll enter again; her title shall be, my dear Lindabrides.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Lindabrides?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Ay, sir, the emperor Alicandro's daughter, and the prince Meridian's sister (In the knight of the sun) she should have been married to him, but that the Princess Claridiana —

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: O, you betray your reading.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Nay, sir, I have read history, I am a little humanitian. Interrupt me not, good sir. My dear Lindabrides, my dear Lindabrides, my dear Lindabrides, methinks you are melancholy.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Ay, and take her by the rosy-fingered hand.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Must I so? O, my dear Lindabrides, methinks you are melancholy.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Or thus, sir. All variety of divine pleasures, choice sports, sweet music, rich fare, brave attire, soft beds, and silken thoughts attend this dear beauty.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Believe me, that's pretty. All variety of divine pleasures, choice sports, sweet music, rich fare, brave attires, soft beds, and silken thoughts, attend this dear beauty.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: And then, offering to kiss her hand, if she shall coily recoil, and signify your repulse; you are to reinforce yourself, with, more than most fair lady, let not the rigour of your just disdain thus coarsely censure of your servant's zeal: and, withal, protest her, to be the only, and absolute unparalleled creature you do adore and admire, and respect, and reverence, in this court, corner of the world, or kingdom.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: This is hard, by my faith. I'll begin it all, again.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Do so, and I will act it for your lady.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Will you vouchsafe, sir? All variety of divine pleasures, choice sports, sweet music, rich fare, brave attire, soft beds, and silken thoughts attend this dear beauty.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: So, sir, pray you away.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: More than most fair lady, let not the rigour of your just disdain, thus courtly censure of your servant's zeal, I protest, you are the only, and absolute, apparel —

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Unparalleled.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Unparalleled creature, I do adore, and admire, and respect, and reverence, in this court, corner of the world, or kingdom.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: This is, if she abide you. But now, put case she should be passant when you enter, as thus: you are to frame your gate thereafter, and call upon her, lady, nymph, sweet refuge, star of our court. Then if she be guardant, here: you are to come on, and (Laterally disposing yourself) swear, by her blushing and well coloured cheek, the bright die of her hair, her morie teeth (Though they be ebony) or some such white, and innocent oath, to induce you. If regardant, then maintain your station, brisk, and irpe, show the supple motion of your pliant body, but (In chief) of your knee, and hand, which cannot but arride her proud humour exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I conceive you, sir, I shall perform all these things in good time, I doubt not, they do so hit me.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Well, sir, I am your lady; make use of any of these beginnings, or some other out of your own invention: and prove, how you can hold up, and follow it. Say, say.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Yes, sir, my dear Lindabrides. —

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: No, you affect that Lindabrides too much. And (Let me tell you) it is not so courtly. Your pedant should provide you some parcels of French, or some pretty commodity of italian to commence with, if you would be exotic, and exquisite.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Yes, sir, he was at my lodging tother morning, I gave him a doublet.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
Double your benevolence, and give him the hose too, clothe you his body, he will help to apparel your mind. But now, see what
your proper genius can perform alone, without adjection of any other Minerva.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I comprehend you, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I do stand you, sir: fall back to your first place. Good, passing well: very properly pursued.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Beautiful, ambiguous, and sufficient lady, what! are you all alone?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: We would be, sir, if you would leave us.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I am at your beauty's appointment, bright angel; but —

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: What but?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: No harm, more than most fair feature.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: That touch relished well.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: But, I protest —

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: And why should you protest?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p:
For good will (Dear esteemed madam) and I hope, your ladyship will so conceive of it:
And will, in time, return from your disdain,
And rue the sufferance of our friendly pain.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: O, that piece was excellent! if you could pick out more of these play-particles, and (As occasion shall salute you) embroider, or damask your discourse with them, persuade your soul, it would most judiciously commend you. Come, this was a well discharged, and auspicious bout. Prove the second.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Lady, I cannot ruffle it in red and yellow.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Why, if you can revel it in white, sir, 'tis sufficient.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Say you so, sweet lady? Lan, tede, de, de, de, daunt, daunt, daunt, dante, etc. No (In good faith) madam, whosoever told your ladyship so, abused you; but I would be glad to meet your ladyship in a measure.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Me, sir? belike you measure me by yourself, then?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Would I might, fair feature.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: And what were you the better, if you might?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: The better it please you to ask, fair lady.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Why, this was ravishing, and most acutely continued. Well, spend not your humour too much, you have now competently exercised your conceit: this (Once or twice a day) will render you an accomplished, elaborate, and well levelled gallant. Convey in your courting-stock, we will (In the heat of this) go visit the nymph's chamber.
I would this water would arrive once, our travailing friend so commended to us.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: So would I, for he has left all us in travail with expectation of it.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Pray Jove, I never rise from this couch, if ever I thirsted more for a thing, in my whole time of being a courtier.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nor I, I'll be sworn: the very mention of it sets my lips in a worse heat, than if he had sprinkled them with Mercury. Reach me the glass, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Here, lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: They do not peel, sweet charge, do they?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes, a little, guardian.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, 'tis an eminent good sign. Ever when my lips do so, I am sure to have some delicious good drink, or other approaching.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Marry, and this may be good for us ladies: for (It seems) 'tis far-fet by their stay.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My palate for yours (Dear honour) it shall prove most elegant, I warrant you: oh, I do fancy this gear that's long a coming, with an unmeasurable strain.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Pray thee sit down, Philautia, that rebato becomes thee singularly.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is't not quaint?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Yes faith. Methinks , thy servant Hedon is nothing so obsequious to thee, as he was wont to be; I know not how, he's grown out of his garb a late, he's warped.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: In trunesse, and so methinks too; he's much converted.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tut, let him be what he will, 'tis an animal I dream not of. This tire ( methinks ) makes me look very ingeniously, quick, and spirited, I should be some Laura, or some Delia, methinks .

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As I am wise (Fair honours) that title she gave him, to be her ambition, spoilt him: before, he was the most propitious and observant young novice —

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: No, no, you are the whole heaven awry, guardian: 'tis the swaggering coach-horse Anaides, draws with him there, has been the diverter of him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: For Cupid's sake, speak no more of him; would I might never dare to look in a mirror again, if I respect ere a marmoset of them all, otherwise, than I would a feather, or my shuttlecock, to make sport with, now and then.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Come, sit down; troth (And you be good beauties) let's run over 'em all now: which is the proper'st man amongst them? I say, the traveler, Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O, fie on him, he looks like a Venetian trumpeter, i' the battle of Lepanto, in the gallery yonder; and speaks to the tune of a country lady, that comes ever i' the rearward, or train of a fashion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I should have judgement in a feature, sweet beauties.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: A body would think so, at these years.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And I prefer another now, far before him, a million at least.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Who might that be, guardian?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Marry (Fair charge) Anaides.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Anaides! you talked of a tune Philautia, there's one speaks in a key: like the opening of some justice's gate, or a post-boy's horn, as if his voice feared an arrest for some ill words it should give, and were loath to come forth.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ay, and he has a very imperfect face.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Like a sea-monster, that were to ravish Andromeda from the rock.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: His hand's too great too, by at least a straw's breadth

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Nay, he has a worse fault than that, too.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: A long heel?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: That were a fault in a lady, rather than him: no, they say, he puts off the calves of his legs, with his stockings, every night.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Out upon him: turn to another of the pictures, for love's sake. What says Argurion? whom does she commend, afore the rest?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I hope, I have instructed her sufficiently for an answer.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Troth, I made the motion to her ladyship for one today, i' the presence, but it appeared she was otherways furnished before: she would none.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Who was that, Argurion?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Marry, the poor plain gentleman, i' the black, there.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Who, Crites?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he. A fellow, that nobody so much as looked upon, or regarded, and she would have had me done him particular grace.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: That was a true trick of yourself, Moria, to persuade Argurion, to affect the scholar.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Tut, but she shall be no chooser for me. In good faith, I like the citizen's son there, Asotus, methinks , none of them all come near him.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Not, Hedon?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Hedon, in troth no. Hedon's a pretty slight courtier, and he wears his clothes well, and sometimes in fashion; marry, his face is but indifferent, and he has no such excellent body. No, th'other is a most delicate youth, a sweet face, a straight body, a well proportioned leg and foot, a white hand, a tender voice.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How now, Argurion?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: O, you should have let her alone, she was bestowing a copy of him upon us. Such a nose were enough to make me love a man, now.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And then his several colours he wears; wherein he flourisheth changeably, every day.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: O, but his short hair, and his narrow eyes!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why, she dotes more palpably upon him, then ere his father did upon her.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p:
Believe me, the young gentleman deserves it. If she could dote more, 'twere not amiss. He is an exceeding proper youth, and
would have made a most neat barber-surgeon, if he had been put to it in time.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Say you so? methinks , he looks like a tailor already.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Ay, that had said on one of his customers suits. His face is like a squeezed orange, or —

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Well, ladies, jest on: the best of you both would be glad of such a servant.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, I'll be sworn would they, though he be a little shamefaced.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Shamefaced, Moria! out upon him. Your shamefaced servant is your only gull.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Go to, beauties, make much of time, and place, and occasion, and opportunity, and favourites, and things that belong to 'em, for I'll ensure you, they will all relinquish; they cannot endure above another year; I know it out of future experience: and therefore take exhibition, and warning. I was once a reveller myself, and though I speak it (As mine own trumpet) I was then esteemed —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: The very marchpane of the court, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: And all the gallants came about you like flies, did they not?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Go to, they did somewhat, that's no matter now.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Nay, good Moria, be not angry. Put case, that we four now had the grant from Juno, to wish ourselves into what happy estate we could? what would you wish to be, Moria?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Who I? Let me see now. I would wish to be a wise woman, and know all the secrets of court, city, and country. I would know what were done behind the arras, what upon the stairs, what i' the garden, what i' the nymph's chamber, what by barge, and what by coach. I would tell you which courtier were scabbed, and which not; which lady had her own face to lie with her a-nights, and which not; who put off their teeth with their clothes in court, who their hair, who their complexion; and in which box they put it. There should not a nymph, or a widow be got with child i' the verge, but I would guess (Within one or two,) who was the right father: and in what month it was gotten; with what words; and which way. I would tell you, which madam loved a monsieur, which a player, which a page; who slept with her husband, who with her friend, who with her gentleman-usher, who with her horsekeeper, who with her monkey, and who with all. Yes, and who jigged the cock too.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Fie, you'd tell all,

sp.speaker: Moria.
sp.p: If I should wish now, it should be to have your tongue out. But what says Philautia? who would she be?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
Troth, the very same I am. Only I would wish myself a little more command, and sovereignty; that all the court were subject to my absolute beck, and all things in it depending on my look; as if there were no other heaven, but in my smile, nor other hell, but in my frown; that I might send for any man I list, and have his head cut off, when I have done with him; or made an eunuch, if he denied me: and if I saw a better
face than mine own, I might have my doctor to poison it. What would you wish, Phantaste?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot (Readily) tell you what ▪ but ( methinks ) I should wish myself all manner of creatures. Now, I would be an empress; and by and by a Duchess; then a great lady of state; then one of your miscellany madams; then a waiting-woman; than your citizen's wife; then a course country gentlewoman; then a dairy maid; then a shepherd's lass; then an empress again, or the Queen of fairies: and thus I would prove the vicissitudes, and whirl of pleasures, about, and again. As I were a shepherdess, I would be piped and sung too; as a dairy wench, I would dance at may-poles, and make syllabubs; as a country gentlewoman, keep a good house, and come up to term, to see motions; as a citizen's wife, be troubled with a jealous husband, and put to my shifts; (Others miseries should be my pleasures) as a waiting-woman, I would taste my lady's delights to her; as a miscellany madam invent new tires, and go visit courtiers; as a great lady, lie a-bed , and have courtiers visit me; as a Duchess, I would keep my state: and as an empress, I'd do any thing. And, in all these shapes, I would ever be followed with th' affections of all that see me. Marry, I myself would affect none; or if I did, it should not be heartily, but so as I might save myself in 'em still, and take pride in tormenting the poor wretches. Or, (Now I think on't) I would, for one year, wish myself one woman, but the richest, fairest, and delicatest in a kingdom, the very centre of wealth, and beauty, wherein all lines of love should meet; and in that person I would prove all manner of suitors, of all humours, and of all complexions, and never have any two of a sort: I would see how love (By the power of his object) could work inwardly alike, in a choleric man, and a sanguine; in a melancholic, and a phlegmatic; in a fool, and a wise man; in a clown, and a courtier; in a valiant man, and a coward: and how he could vary outward, by letting this gallant express himself in dumb gaze; another with sighing, and rubbing his fingers; a third, with play-ends, and pitiful verses; a fourth, with stabbing himself, and drinking healths, or writing languishing letters in his blood; a fifth, in coloured ribbons, and good clothes; with this lord to smile, and that lord to court, and the tother lord to dote, and one lord to hang himself. And then, I to have a book made of all this, which I would call the book of humours, and every night read a little piece, ere I slept, and laugh at it. Here comes Hedon.

div.head: Act iv. Scene ii.
div.stage: Hedon, Anaides, Mercury, Phantaste, Philautia, Moria, Argurion, Cupid.

sp.p: Save you, sweet and clear beauties: by the spirit that moves in me, you are all most pleasingly bestowed, ladies. Only, I can take it for no good omen, to find mine honour so dejected.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You need not fear, sir, I did of purpose humble myself against your coming, to decline the pride of my ambition.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Fair honour, ambition dares not stoop; but if it be your sweet pleasure, I shall lose that title, I will (As I am Hedon) apply myself to your bounties.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: That were the next way to distil myself of honour. O, no, rather be still ambitious, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: I will be any thing that you please, whilst it pleaseth you to be yourself, lady. Sweet Phantaste, dear Moria, most beautiful Argurion —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Farewell, Hedon.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Anaides, stay, whither go you?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Slight, what should I do here? and you engross 'em all for your own use, 'tis time for me to seek out.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Ay, engross 'em? Away, mischief, this is one of your extravagantiests now, because I began to salute 'em by their names —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Faith, you might have spared us madam prudence, the guardian there, though you had more covetously aimed at the rest.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: S'heart, take 'em all, man: what speak you to me of aiming, or covetous?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ay, say you so? nay, then, have at 'em: ladies, here's one hath distinguished you by your names already. It shall only become me, to ask, how you do?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: God's so, was this the design you travailed with?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Who answers the brazen head? it spoke to somebody .

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Lady wisdom, do you interpret for these puppets?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: In truth, and sadness (Honours) you are in great offence for this, go too: the gentleman (I'll undertake with him) is a man of fair living, and able to maintain a lady in her two caroches a day, besides pages, monkeys, and parachitos, with such attendants as she shall think meet for her turn, and therefore there is more respect requirable, howsoe'er you seem to connive. Hark you, sir, let me discourse a syllable with you. I am to say to you, these ladies are not of that close, and open behaviour, as happily you may suspend; their carriage is well known, to be such as it should be, both gentle and extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, here comes the other pair.

div.head: Act iv. Scene iii.
div.stage: Amorphus, Asotus, Hedon, Anaides, Mercury, Cupid, Phantaste, Philautia, Argurion, Moria.

sp.p: That was your father's love, the nymph Argurion. I would have you direct all your courtship thither, if you could but endear yourself to her affection, you were eternally engallanted.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: In truth, sir? pray Phoebus I prove favour-some in her fair eyes.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: All divine mixture, and increase of beauty to this bright bevy of ladies; and to the male-courtiers, compliment, and courtesy.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: In the behalf of the males, I gratify you, Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: And I, of the females.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Succinctly returned. I do vale to both your thanks, and kiss them: but primarily to yours, most ingenious, acute, and polite lady.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: God's my life, how he does all to bequalify her! ingenious, acute, and polite? as if there were not others in place as ingenious, acute, and polite, as she.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Yes, but you must know, lady, he cannot speak out of a dictionary method.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Sit down, sweet Amorphus: when will this water come, think you?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: It cannot now be long, fair lady.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Now observe, Mercury.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: How? most ambiguous beauty? love you? that I will by this handkercher.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Slid, he draws his oaths out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: But, will you be constant?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Constant, madam? I will not say for constantness, but by this purse (Which I would be loath to swear by, unless 'twere embroidered) I protest (More than most fair lady) you are the only, absolute, and unparallelled creature, I do adore, and admire, and respect, and reverence in this court, corner of the world, or kingdom: methinks you are melancholy.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Does your heart speak all this?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Say you? —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O, he is groping for another oath.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Now, by this watch (I made how forward the day is) I do unfeignedly vow myself ('slight 'tis deeper than I took it, passed five) yours entirely addicted, madam.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: I require no more, dearest Asotus, henceforth let me call you mine, and in remembrance of me, vouchsafe to wear this chain, and this diamond.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: O god, sweet lady!

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: There are new oaths for him: what? doth Hermes taste no alteration, in all this?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, thou hast struck Argurion enamoured on Asotus, the thinks.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Alas, no; I am nobody, I: I can do nothing in this disguise.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But thou hast not wounded any of the rest, Cupid?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Not yet: it is enough that I have begun so prosperously.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Nay, these are nothing to the gems I will hourly bestow upon thee: be but faithful, and kind to me, and I will lade thee with my richest bounties: behold, here my bracelets, from mine arms.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Not so, good lady, by this diamond.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Take 'em, wear 'em: my jewels, chain of pearl, pendants, all I have.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Nay then, by this pearl, you make me a wanton.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Shall not she answer for this, to maintain him thus in swearing?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O, no, there is a way to wean him from this, the gentleman may be reclaimed.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Ay, if you had the ayring of his apparel, cousin, I think.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Loving? 'twere pity I should be living else, believe me. Save you, sir. Save you, sweet lady. Save you, monsieur Anaides. Save you, dear madam.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Dost thou know him that saluted thee, Hedon?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: No, some idle Fungoso, that hath got above the cupboard, since yesterday.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Sblood, I never saw him till this morning, and he salutes me as familiarly, as if we had known together, since the deluge, or the first year of troy-action.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: A most right-handed, and auspicious encounter. Confine yourself to your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: For sport's sake, let's have some riddles, or purposes; hough.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: No faith, your prophecies are best, the tother are stale.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Prophecies? we cannot all sit in at them; we shall make a confusion. No; what called you that we had in the forenoon?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Substantives, and adjectives. Is't not Hedon?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ay, that, who begins?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: I have thought; speak your adjectives, sirs.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But do not you change, then?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Not I, who says?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Odoriferous.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Popular.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Humble.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: White-livered.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Barbarous.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: This was not so good, now.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: In good faith, these unhappy pages would be whipped, for staying thus.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Beshrew my hand, and my heart, else.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I do wonder at their protraction!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Pray Venus, my whore have not discovered herself to the rascally hoys, and that be the cause of their stay.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I must suit myself with another page: this idle Prosaites will never be brought to wait well.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Sir, I have a kinsman I could willingly wish to your service, if you would deign to accept of him.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: And I shall be glad (Most sweet lady) to embrace him: where is he?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I can fetch him, sir, but I would be loath to make you turn away your other page.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: You shall not, most sufficient lady, I will keep both: pray you let's go see him.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Whither goes my love?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I'll return presently, I go but to see a page, with this lady.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: As sure as fate, 't is so; she has opened all: a pox of all cockatrices. Dam'me, if she have played loose with me, I'll cut her throat, within a hair's breadth, so it may be healed again.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What, is he jealous of his hermaphrodite?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: O, ay, this will be excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Phantaste! Argurion! what? you are suddenly struck, methinks ! for love's sake let's have some music, till they come. Ambition, reach the lyra, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Any thing to which my honour shall direct me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Come, Amorphus, cheer up Phantaste.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: It shall be my pride, fair lady, to attempt all that is in my power. But here is an instrument that (Alone) is able to infuse soul in the most melancholic, and dull disposed creature upon earth. O! let me kiss thy fair knees. Beauteous ears attend it.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Will you have the kiss, honour?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ay, good ambition.
sp.l: O, that joy so soon should waste!
Or so sweet a bliss
As a kiss,
Might not for ever last!
So sugared, so melting, so soft, so delicious,
The dew that lies on roses,
When the morn herself discloses,
Is not so precious.
O, rather than I would it smother,
Were I to taste such another;
It should be my wishing
That I might die kissing.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: I made this ditty, and the note to it, upon a kiss that my honour gave me; how like you it, sir?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: A pretty air, in general, I like it well: but in particular, your long die-note did arride me most, but it was somewhat too long. I can show one, almost of the same nature, but much before it and not so long, in a composition of mine own. I think I have both the note, and ditty about me.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Pray you, sir, see.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Yes, there is the note; and all the parts if I misthink not. I will read the ditty to your beauties here, but first I am to make you familiar with the occasion, which presents itself thus. Upon a time, going to take my leave of the emperor, and kiss his great hands; there being then present, the Kings of France, and Arragon, the Dukes of Savoy, Florence ▪ orleance, Bourbon, Brunswick, the landgrave, count Palatine, all which had severally feasted me; besides, infinite more of inferior persons, as counts and others it was my chance the emperor detained by some exorbitant affair) to wait him the fifth part of an hour, or much near it. In which time (Retiring myself into a bay-window) the beauteous lady Annabell, niece to the empress, and sister to the King of Arragon, who having never before eyed me, (But only heard the common report of my virtue, learning, and travail) fell into that extremity of passion, for my love, that she there immediately swooned: physicians were sent for, she had to her chamber, so to her bed; where (Languishing some few days) after many times calling upon me, with my name in her lips, she expired. As that (I must mourningly say) is the only fault of my fortune, that, as it hath ever been my hap to be sewed to, by all ladies, and beauties, where I have come, so, I never yet sojourned, or rested in that place, or part of the world, where some high-born admirable fair feature died not for my love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O, the sweet power of travail! are you guilty of this, Cupid?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: No, Mercury, and that his page (Cos) knows, if he were here present to be sworn.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But, how doth this draw on the ditty, sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O, she is too quick with him; he hath not devised that yet.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Marry, some hour before she departed, she bequeathed to me this glove; which golden legacy, the emperor himself took care to send after me, in six coaches, covered all with black vellet, attended by the state of his empire; all which he freely presented me with, and I reciprocally (Out of the same bounty) gave to the lords that brought it: only reserving the gift of the deceased lady, upon which I composed this ode, and set it to my most affected instrument, the lyra.
sp.l: Thou more than most sweet glove,
Unto my more sweet love,
Suffer me to store with kisses
This empty lodging, that now misses
The pure rosy hand, that beware thee,
Whiter than the kid, that bore thee.
Thou art soft, but that was softer;
Cupid's self hath kissed it ofter,
Than e'er he did his mother's doves,
Supposing her the Queen of loves,
That was thy mistress,
Best of gloves.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Blasphemy, blasphemy, Cupid.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Ay, I'll revenge it time enough; Hermes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Good Amorphus, let's hear it sing.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I care not to admit that, since it pleaseth Philautia to request it.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: after he hath sung. nay, play it, I pray you, you do well, you do well — how like you it, sir?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Very well in troth.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: But very well? O, you are a mere mammothrept in judgement then. Why, do you not observe how excellently the ditty is affected in every place? that I do not marry a word of short quantity to a long note? nor an ascending syllable to a descending tone? Besides, upon the word (Best) there, you see how I do enter with an odd minnum, and drive it thorough the brief, which no intelligent musician (I know) but will affirm to be very rare, extraordinary, and pleasing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And yet not fit to lament the death of a lady, for all this.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Tut, here be they will swallow any thing.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Pray you let me have a copy of it, Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And me too, in troth, I like it exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I have denied it to princes, nevertheless to you (The true female twins of perfection) I am won, to depart withal.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: I hope I shall have my honour's copy.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: who is returned from seeking his page. you are ambitious in that, Hedon.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: How now, Anaides! what is it hath conjured up this distemperature in the circle of your face?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Sblood, what have you to do? A pox upon your filthy travailing face, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Nay, dost hear, mischief?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Away, musk-cat.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I say to thee, thou art rude, debauched, impudent, course, impolished, a frapler, and base.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Heart of my father, what a strange alteration has half a year's haunting of ordinaries wrought in this fellow! that came with a tuss-taffeta jerkin to town but the other day, and a pair of penniless hose, and now he is turned Hercules, he wants but a club.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Sir, you with the pencil on your chin; I will garter my hose with your guts, and that shall be all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Slid, what rare fireworks be here? flash, flash.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: What's the matter Hedon? can you tell?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Nothing, but that he lacks crowns, and thinks we'll lend him some, to be friends.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Come,Asotus returns with Moria, and Morus. sweet lady, in good truth I'll have it, you shall not deny me. Morus, persuade your aunt I may have her picture, by any means.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, sir: good aunt now, let him have it, he will use me the better, if you love me, do, good aunt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, tell him, he shall have it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Master, you shall have it, she says.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Shall I? thank her, good page.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What, has he entertained the fool?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, he'll wait close, you shall see, though the beggar hang off, awhile.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Aunt, my master thanks you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Call him hither.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, master

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, in verity, and gave me this purse, and he has promised me a most fine dog; which he will have drawn, with my picture, he says: and desires most vehemently to be known to your ladyships.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Call him hither, 'tis good groping such a gull.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Master Asotus, master Asotus.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: For love's sake, let me go: you see, I am called to the ladies.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Wilt thou forsake me then?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: God so, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Come hither, master Asotus. I do ensure your ladyships, he is a gentleman of a very worthy desert: and of a most bountiful nature. You must show and insinuate yourself responsible, and equivalent now to my commendment. Good honours, grace him.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I protest (More than most fair ladies) I do wish all variety of divine pleasures, choice sports, sweet music, rich fare, brave attire, soft beds, and silken thoughts attend these fair beauties. Will it please your ladyship to wear this chain of pearl, and this diamond, for my sake?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: And you, madam, this jewel, and pendants.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: We know not how to deserve these bounties, out of so slight merit, Asotus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No, in faith, but there's my glove for a favour.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: And soon, after the revels, I will bestow a garter on you.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: O lord, ladies! it is more grace than ever I could have hoped, but that it pleaseth your ladyships to extend. I protest, it is enough, that you but take knowledge of my — if your ladyship's want embroidered gowns, tires of any fashion, rebatoes, jewels, or carcanets, any thing whatsoever, if you vouchsafe to accept.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: And for it, they will help you to shoe-ties, and devices.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I cannot utter myself (Dear beauties) but, you can conceive —

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Sir, we will acknowledge your service, doubt not: henceforth, you shall be no more Asotus to us, but our goldfinch, and we your cages.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: O Venus, madams! how shall I deserve this? if I were but made acquainted with Hedon, now, I'll try: pray you away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How he prays money to go away from him!

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Amorphus, a word with you: here's a watch I would bestow upon you, pray you make me known to that gallant.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: That I will, sir. Monsieur Hedon, I must entreat you to exchange knowledge with this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: 'Tis a thing (Next to the water we expect) I thirst after, sir ▪ good Monsieur Asotus.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Good monsieur Hedon, I would be glad to be loved of men of your rank, and spirit, I protest. Please you to accept this pair of bracelets, sir: they are not worth the bestowing —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O, Hercules, how the gentleman purchases! this must needs bring Argurion to a consumption.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Sir, I shall never stand in the merit of such bounty, I fear.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: O, Venus, sir; your acquaintance shall be sufficient. And if at any time you need my bill, or my bond.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Argurion swoons. o, Ô.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Help the lady there.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: God's dear, Argurion! Madam, how do you?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Sick.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Have her forth, and give her air.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I come again straight, ladies.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, I doubt, all the physic he has will scarce recover her: she's too far spent.

div.head: Act iv. Scene iiii.
div.stage: Philautia, Gelaia, Anaides, Cos, Prosaites, Phantaste, Moria, Amorphus, Hedon.

sp.p: O here's the water come: fetch glasses, page.

sp.speaker: Gel.
sp.p: Heart of my body, here's a coil indeed, with your jealous humours. Nothing but whore, and bitch, and all the villainous swaggering names you can think on? 'slid, take your bottle, and put it in your guts for me, I'll see you poxed ere I follow you any longer.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Nay, good punk, sweet rascal; damn me, if I am jealous now.

sp.speaker: Gel.
sp.p: That's true indeed: pray let's go.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What's the matter, there?

sp.speaker: Gel.
sp.p: 'Slight, he has me upon intergatories, (Nay, my mother shall know how you use me) where I have been? and, why I should stay so long? and, how is't possible? and withal, calls me at his pleasure, I know not how many cockatrices, and things.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: In truth and sadness, these are no good epitaphs, Anaides, to bestow upon any gentlewoman; and (I'll ensure you) if I had known you would have dealt thus with my daughter, she should never have fancied you so deeply, as she has done. Go too.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Why, do you hear, mother Moria. Heart!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you, sir, do not swear.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Swear? why? 'sblood, I have sworn afore now, I hope. Both you and your daughter mistake me. I have not honoured Arete, that is held the worthiest lady in court (Next to Cynthia) with half that observance, and respect, as I have done her in private, howsoever outwardly I have carried myself careless, and negligent. Come, you are a foolish, punk, and know not when you are well employed. Kiss me, come on. Do it, I say.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, indeed I must confess, she is apt to misprision. But I must have you leave it, minion.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: How now, Asotus? how does the lady?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Faith, ill. I have left my page with her, at her lodging.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: O, here's the rarest water that ever was tasted: fill him some.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What! has my master a new page?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, a kinsman of the lady Morias: you must wait better now, or you are cashiered, Prosaites.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Come, gallants, you must pardon my foolish humour: when I am angry, that any thing crosses me, I grow impatient straight. Here, I drink to you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O, that we had five, or six bottles more of this liquor.

The noble, and subtle science of courtship: for which grace, he shall this night in court, and in the long gallery, hold his public act, by open challenge, to all masters of the mystery whatsoever, to play at the four choice, and principal weapons thereof, viz. the bare accost, the better regard, the solemn address, and the perfect close. What say you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Excellent, excellent, Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Well, let us then take our time by the forehead: I will instantly have bills drawn, and advanced in every angle of the court. Sir, betray not your too much joy. Anaides, we must mix this gentleman with you in acquaintance, monsieur Asotus.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: I am easily entreated to grace any of your friends, Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Sir, and his friends shall likewise grace you, sir. Nay, I begin to know myself, now.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: O, you must continue your bounties.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Must I? why, I'll give him this ruby on my finger. Do you hear, sir? I do heartily with your acquaintance, and I partly know myself worthy of it; please you, sir, to accept this poor ruby, in a ring, sir. The poesy is of my own device. Let this blush for me, sir.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: So it must for me, too. For I am not ashamed to take it.

sp.speaker: Morus.
sp.p: Sweet man! by my troth, master, I love you, will you love me, too? for my ants sake? I'll wait well, you shall see. I'll still be here. Would I might never stir, but you are a fine man in these clothes, master, shall I have 'em, when you have done with them?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: As for that, Morus, thou shalt see more hereafter: in the mean time, by this air, or by this feather, I'll do as much for thee, as any gallant shall do for his page, whatsoever, in this court, corner of the world, or kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I wonder, this gentleman should affect to keep a fool! methinks , he makes sport enough with himself.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Well, Prosaites, 'twere good you did wait closer.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Ay, I'll look to it; 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.p: The revels would have been most sumptuous tonight , if they had gone forward.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: They must needs, when all the choicest singularities of the court were up in pantofles; never a one of them, but was able to make a whole show of itself.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: within. sirrah, a torch, a torch.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: O, what a call is there! I will have a canzonet made, with nothing in it, but sirrah; and the burden shall be, I come.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How now, Cupid, how do you like this change?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Faith, the thread of my device is cracked, I may go sleep till the revelling music awake me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And there too, Cupid, without you had prevented the fountain. Alas, poor god, that remembers not self-love, to be proof
against the violence of his quiver! Well, I have a plot upon these prisers, for which, I must presently find out Crites, and with his assistance, pursue it to a high strain of laughter, or Mercury hath lost of his mettle.

sp.l: It is resolved on, Crites, you must do it.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: The grace divinest Mercury hath done me,
In this vouchsafed discovery of himself,
Binds my observance in the utmost term
Of satisfaction, to his godly will:
Though I profess (Without the affectation)
Of an enforced, and formed austerity)
I could be willing to enjoy no place
With so unequal natures.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: We believe it.
But for our sake, and to inflict just pains
On their prodigious follies, aid us now:
No man is, presently, made bad, with ill.
And good men, like the sea, should still maintain
Their noble taste, in midst of all fresh humours,
That flow about them, to corrupt their streams,
Bearing no season, much less salt of goodness.
It is our purpose, Crites, to correct,
And punish, with our laughter, this night's sport
Which our court-dors so heartily intend:
And by that worthy scorn, to make them know
How far beneath the dignity of man
Their serious, and most practised actions are.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Ay, but though Mercury can warrant out
His under-takings, and make all things good,
Out of the powers of his divinity,
Th'offence will be returned with weight on me,
That am a creature so despised, and poor;
When the whole court shall take itself abused
By our ironical confederacy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are deceived. The better race in court
That have the true nobility, called virtue,
Will apprehend it, as a grateful right
Done to their separate merit: and approve
The fit rebuke of so ridiculous heads,
Who with their apish customs, and forced garbs,
Would bring the name of courtier in contempt,
Did it not live unblemished in some few,
whom equal Jove hath loved, and Phoebus formed
Of better mettle, and in better mould.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Well, since my leader on is Mercury,
I shall not fear to follow. If I fall,
My proper virtue shall be my relief,
That followed such a cause, and such a chief.

sp.p: No more, if you love me, good master, you are incompatible to live withal: send me for the ladies.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Nay, but intend me.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Fear me not, I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Render not yourself a refractory, on the sudden. I can allow well, you should repute highly, heartily (And to the most) of your own endowments; it gives you forth to the world the more assured: but with reservation of an eye, to be always turned dutifully back upon your teacher.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Nay, good, sir, leave it to me. Trust me with trussing all the points of this action, I pray. 'slid, I hope we shall find wit to perform the science, as well as another.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I confess you to be of an aped, and docible humour. Yet, there are certain punctilioes, or (As I may more nakedly insinuate them) certain intrinsicate strokes, and wards, to which your activity is not yet amounted. As your gentile dor, in colours. For supposition, your mistress appears here in prize, ribbanded with green, and yellow; now it is the part of every obsequious servant, to be sure to have daily about him copy, and variety of colours, to be presently answerable to any hourly, or half-hourly change in his mistress revolution. —

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: (I know it, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Give leave, I pray you) which if your antagonist, or player-against-you shall ignorantly be without, and yourself can produce; you give him the dor.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Ay, ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Or, if you can possess your opposite, that the green your mistress wears, is her rejoicing or exultation in his service; the yellow, suspicion of his truth, (From her height of affection:) and that he (Greenly credulous) shall withdraw thus, in private, and from the abundance of his pocket (To displace her jealous conceit) steal into his hat the colour, whose blueness doth express trueness, (She being nor so, nor so affected) you give him the dor.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Do not I know it, sir?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Nay, good — swell not above your understanding. There is yet a third dor, in colours.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: I know it too, I know it.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Do you know it too? what is it? Make good your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Why it is — no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Do it, on poene of the dor.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Why? what is't, say you?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Lo, you have given yourself the dor. But I will remonstrate to you the third dor; which is not, as the two former dors, indicative, but deliberative: as how? As thus. Your rivalis, with a dutiful, and serious care, lying in his bed, meditating how to observe his mistress, dispatcheth his lackey to the chamber, early, to know what her colours are for the day; with purpose to apply his wear that day, accordingly: you lay wait before, preoccupy the chambermaid, corrupt her, to return false colours; he follows the fallacy; comes out accoutred to his believed instructions; your mistress smiles; and you give him the dor.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Why, so I told you, sir, I knew it.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Told me? It is a strange outrecuidance! your humour too much redoundeth.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Why, sir, what, do you think you know more?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I know that a cook may as soon, and properly be said to smell well, as you to be wise. I know these are most clear, and clean strokes. But then, you have your passages, and imbrocatas in courtship; as the bitter rob in wit; the reverse in face, or wry-mouth; and these more subtle, and secure offenders. I will example unto you. Your opponent makes entry, as you are engaged with your mistress. You seeing him, close in her ear, with this whisper (Here comes your baboon, disgrace him) and withal, stepping off, fall on his bosom, and turning to her, politicly, aloud say, lady, regard this noble gentleman, a man rarely parted, second to none in this court; and then, stooping over his shoulder, your hand on his breast, your mouth on his backside, you give him the reverse stroke, with this Sanna, or storks-bill, which makes up your wits bob, most bitter.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Nay, for heaven's sake, teach me no more. I know all as well — 'slid, if I did not, why was I nominated? why did you choose me? why did the ladies prick out me? I am sure there were other gallants. But me of all the rest? By that light, and as I am a courtier, would I might never stir, but 'tis strange. Would to the lord, the ladies would come once.

div.head: Act v. scene iii.
div.stage: Morphides, Amorphus, Asotus, Hedon, Anaides, the throng. Ladies, citizen, wife, pages, tailor, mercer, perfumer, jeweller, etc.

sp.p: Signior, the gallants and ladies are at hand. Are you ready, sir?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Instantly. Go, accomplish your attire: cousin Morphides, assist me, to make good the door with your officious tyranny.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: By your leave my masters there, pray you let's come by.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: You by? why should you come by, more than we?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Why, sir? Because he is my brother, that plays the prizes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your brother?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Ay, her brother, sir, and we must come in.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Why, what are you?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am her husband, sir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Then thrust forward your head.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: What tumult is there?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Who's there? bear back there. Stand from the door.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Enter none but the ladies, and their hang_byes; welcome beauties, and your kind shadows.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: This country lady, my friend, good signior Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: And my cockatrice, here.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: She is welcome.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Knock those same pages there; and goodman coxcomb the citizen, who would you speak withal?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: With whom? your brother?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Who is your brother?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Master Asotus? Is he your brother? He is taken up with great persons. He is not to know you tonight .

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: O Jove, master! and there come ere a citizen gentlewoman in my name, let her have entrance, I pray you. It is my sister.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Brother, master Asotus.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: 'Tis I, brother.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: God's me! There she is, good master, intrude he.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Make place. Bear back there.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Knock that simple fellow, there.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay, good sir; it is my husband.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The simpler fellow he. Away, back with your head, sir.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Brother, you must pardon your nonentry: husbands are not allowed here in truth. I'll come home soon with my sister; pray you meet us with a lantern, brother. Be merry, sister: I shall make you laugh anon.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Your prizer is not ready Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Apprehend your places, he shall be soon; and at all points.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Is there anybody come to answer him? Shall we have any sport.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Sport of importance; howsoever, give me the gloves.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Gloves! why gloves, signior?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: he distributes gloves. what's the ceremony?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Besides their received fitness, at all prizes, they are here properly accommodate to the nuptials of my scholar's behaviour to the lady courtship. Please you apparel your hands. Madam Phantaste, madam Philautia, guardian, signior Hedon, signior Anaides, gentlemen all, ladies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thanks, good Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I will now call forth my Provost, and present him.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Heart! why should not we be masters, as well as he?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: That's true, and play our master's prizes, as well as the tother?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: In sadness, for using your court-weapons, methinks , you may.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Nay, but why should not we ladies play our prizes, I pray? I see no reason, but we should take 'em down, at their own weapons.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Troth, and so we may, if we handle 'em well.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I indeed, forsooth, madam, if 'twere i' the city, we would think foul scorn, but we would, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Pray you, what should we call your name?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: My name is, downfall.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Good mistress downfall! I am sorry, your husband could not get in.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for him, sir.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: No, no, she has the more liberty for herself.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Peace,a flourish. peace: they come.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
So. Keep up your ruff: the tincture of your neck is not all so pure, but it will ask it. Maintain your sprig upright; your cloak on your half-shoulder falling; so: I will read your bill, advance it, and present you. Silence.
Be it known to all that profess courtship,the challenge by these presents (From the white satin reveller, to the cloth of tissue, and bodkin) that we, ulysses-polytropus-amorphus, master of the noble, and subtle science of courtship, do give leave and licence to our Provost, Acolastus-polypragmon-asotus, to play his master's prize, against all masters whatsoever in this subtle mystery, at these four, the choice, and most cunning weapons of court-complement, viz. the bare accost; the better regard; the solemn address; and the perfect close. These are therefore to give notice, to all comers, that he, she said Acolastus-polypragmon-asotus, is here present (By the help of his mercer, tailor, milliner, sempster, and so forth) at his designed hour, in this fair gallery, the present day of this present month, to perform, and do his uttermost for the achievement, and bearing away of the prizes, which are these: viz. for the bare accost, two wall-eyes, in a face forced: for the better regard, a face favourably simpering, with a farm waving: for the solemn address, two lips wagging, and never a wise word: for the perfect close, a wring by the hand, with a banquet in a corner. And Phoebus save Cynthia.
Appeareth no man yet, to answer the prizer? No voice? Music, give them their summons. music sounds.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: The solemnity of this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Silence. Well, I perceive your name is their terror; and keepeth them back.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p:
i'faith, master, let's go: nobody comes. Victus, victa,
victum; victi, victae, victi — let's be retrograde.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Stay. That were dispunct to the ladies. Rather, ourself shall be your encounter. Take your state, up, to the wall: and, lady, may we implore you to stand forth, as first term, or bound to our courtship.

sp.speaker: H●d.
sp.p: a charge. before heaven, 'twill show rarely.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Sound a charge.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: A pox on't. Your vulgar will count this fabulous, and impudent, now: by that candle, they'll never conceit it.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Excellent well! Admirable!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: they act their accost severally to the lady that stands forth. most fashionably, believe it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O, he is a well-spoken gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Now the other.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: For a scholar, honour.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: O, 'tis too Dutch. He reels too much.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: a flourish. this weapon is done.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: No, we have our two bouts, at every weapon, expect.
Where be these gallants, and their brave prizer here?

sp.speaker: Morp.
sp.p: Who's there? bear back: keep the door.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: C●it.
sp.p: By your licence, grand-master. Come forward, sir.

sp.speaker: Anai.
sp.p: Heart! who let in that rag there, amongst us? put him out, an impecunious creature.

sp.speaker: Hedo.
sp.p: Out with him.

sp.speaker: Mor●.
sp.p: Come, sir.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: You must be retrograde.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: Soft, sir, I am truchman, and do flourish before this monsieur, or french-behaved gentleman, here; who is drawn hither by report of your cartels, advanced in court, to prove his fortune with your prizer, so he may have fair play shown him, and the liberty to choose his stickler.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Is he a master?

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: That, sir, he has to show here; and, confirmed under the hands of the most skilful, and cunning complementaries alive: please you read, sir.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Anai.
sp.p: Death, disgrace this fellow i' the black-stuff, whatever you do.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why, but he comes with the stranger.

sp.speaker: Hedo.
sp.p: That's no matter. He is our own countryman.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ay, and he is a scholar besides. You may disgrace him here, with authority.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Well, see these first.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Now shall I be observed by yond scholar, till I sweat again; I would to Jove, it were over.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Sir, this is the wight of worth, that dares you to the encounter. A gentleman of so pleasing, and ridiculous a carriage; as, even standing, carries meat in the mouth, you see; and I assure you, although no bred courtling, yet a most particular man, of goodly havings, well fashioned behaviour, and of as hardened, and excellent a bark, as the most naturally-qualified amongst them, informed, reformed, and transformed, from his original criticism, by this elixir, or mere magazine of man. And, for your spectators, you behold them, what they are: the most choice particulars in court: this tells tales well; this provides coaches; this repeats jests; this presents gifts ▪ this holds up the arras; this takes down from horse; this protests by this light; this swears by that candle; this delighteth; this adoreth. Yet, all but three men. Then for your ladies, the most proud witty creatures, all things apprehending, nothing understanding, perpetually laughing, curious maintainers of fools, mercers, and minstrels, costly to be kept, miserably keeping, all disdaining, but their painter, and apothecary, twixt whom and them there is this reciproque commerce, their beauties maintain their painters, and their painters their beauties.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sir, you have played the painter yourself, and limbed them to the life. I desire to deserve before 'em.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: This is authentic. having read the certificate. we must resolve to entertain the monsieur, howsoever we neglect him.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Come, let's all go together, and salute him.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Content, and not look of the other.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Well devised: and a most punishing disgrace.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: On.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Monsieur. We must not so much betray ourselves to discourtship, as to suffer you to be longer unsaluted: please you to use the state, ordained for the opponent; in which nature, without envy we receive you.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: And embrace you.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: And commend us to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Believe it, he is a man of excellent silence.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: He keeps all his wit for action.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: This hath discountenanced our scholaris, most richly.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Out of all emphasis. The Monsieur sees, we regard him not.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Hold on: make it known how bitter a thing it is, not to be looked on in court.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: 'Sblood, will he call him to him yet? does not Monsieur perceive our disgrace?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Heart! he is a fool, I see. We have done ourselves wrong to grace him.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: 'Slight, what an ass was I, to embrace him?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Illustrious, and fearful judges —

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Turn away, turn away.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: It is the suit of the strange opponent (To whom you ought not to turn your tails, and whose noses I must follow) that he may have the justice, before he encounter his respected adversary, to see some light stroke of his play, commenced with some other.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Answer not him, but the stranger, we will not believe him.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I will demand him myself.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: O dreadful disgrace, if a man were so foolish to feel it!

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Is it your suit, monsieur, to see some prelude of my scholar? Now, sure the Monsieur wants language.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: And take upon him to be one of the accomplished? 'slight, that's a goodiest: would we could take him with that nullity. Non sapette voi parlar' itagliano?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, the carp has no tongue.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Signior, in courtship, you are to bid your abettors forbear, and satisfy the monsieurs request.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Well, I will strike him more silent, with admiration, and terrify his daring hither. He shall behold my own play, with my scholar. Lady, with the touch of your white hand, let me reinstate you. Provost, begin to me,a charge. at the bare accost. Now, for the honour of my discipline.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Signior Amorphus, reflect, reflect: what means he by that mouthed wave?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: He is in some distaste of your fellow disciple.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Signior, your scholar might have played well still, if he could have kept his fear longer: I have enough of him, now. He is a mere piece of glass, I see through him, by this time.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: You come not to give us the scorn, monsieur?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nor to be frighted with a face. Signior! I have seen the lions. You must pardon me. I shall be loath to hazard a reputation with one, that has not a reputation to lose.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Meaning your pupil, sir.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: This is that black devil there.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: You do offer a strange affront, monsieur.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Sir, he shall yield you all the honour of a competent adversary, if you please to undertake him —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I am pressed for the encounter.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Me? challenge me?

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: What! my master, sir? 'slight, monsieur, meddle with me, do you hear? but do not meddle with my master.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Peace, good squib, go out.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: And stink, he bids you.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Master?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Silence, I do accept him. Sit you down, and observe. Me? He never professed a thing at more charges. Prepare yourself, sir. Challenge me? I will prosecute what disgrace my hatred can dictate to me.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: How tender a traveller's spleen is? comparison, to men, that deserve least, is ever most offensive.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: You are instructed in our chartell, and know our weapons?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I appear not without their notice, sir.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: But must I lose the prizes, master?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I will win them for you, be patient. Lady, vouchsafe the tenure of this ensign. Who shall be your stickler?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Behold him.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I would not wish you a weaker. Sound musics. I provoke you, at the bare accost.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Excellent comely! a charge.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: And worthily studied. This is th' exalted foretop.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: O, his leg was too much produced.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: And his hat was carried skiruily.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peace; let's see the monsieurs accost: rare!

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Sprightly, and short.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: True, it is the French curteau: he lacks but to have his nose slit.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: He does hop. a flourish. he does bound too much.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: The second bout,a charge. to conclude this weapon.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Good, believe it!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: An excellent offer!

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: This is called the solemn bandstring.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Foe, that cringe was not put home.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, he makes a face like a stabbed Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Well, he would needs take it upon him, but would I had done it for all this. He makes me sit still here, like a baboon as I am.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Making villainous faces.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: See, the French prepares it richly.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Ay, this is yclept the serious trifle.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Sblood, 'tis the horse-start out of the brown study.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Rather the bird-eyed stroke,a flourish. sir. Your observance is too blunt, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Judges, award the prize. Take breath, sir. This bout hath been laborious.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: And yet your critic, or your besso'gno, will think these things foppery, and easy, now.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Or rather mere lunacy. For, would any reasonable creature make these his serious studies, and perfections? Much less, only live to these ends? to be the false pleasure of a few, the true love of none, and the just laughter of all?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: We must prefer the monsieur, we courtiers must be partial.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Speak, guardian. Name the prize, at the bare accost.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A pair of wall-eyes, in a face forced.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Give the monsieur. Amorphus hath lost his eyes.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I! is the palate of your judgement down? Gentles, I do appeal.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Yes master, to me. The judges be fools.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: How now, sir? Tie up your tongue, mongrel. He cannot appeal.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Say you, sir?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Sir you still, sir.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: Why, so I do. Do not I, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Remercy, madam, and these honourable censors.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Well, to the second weapon, the better regard: I will encounter you better. Attempt.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Sweet honour.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What says my good ambition?

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Which take you at this next weapon? I lay a discretion, with you, on Amorphus head.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why, I take the french-behaved gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: 'Tis done, a discretion.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: A discretion? A pretty court-wager! would any discreet person hazard his wit, so?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: I'll lay a discretion, with you, Anaides.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Hang 'em. I'll not venture a doit of discretion, on either of their heads. —

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: No, he should venture all then.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: I like none of their plays.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: a charge. see, see, this is strange play!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Tis too full of uncertain motion. He hobbles too much.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: 'Tis called your court-staggers, sir.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: That same fellow talks so, now he has a place.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Hang him, neglect him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your good ladyship's affectioned.

sp.speaker: Wi●.
sp.p: God's so! they speak at this weapon, brother!

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.p: They must do so, sister, how should it be the better regard, else?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: methinks , he did not this respectively enough.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why, the monsieur but dallies with him.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Dallies? 'slight see, he'll put him to't, in earnest. Well done, Amorphus.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: That puff was good indeed.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: God's me! This is desperate play. He hits himself o'the shins.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: And he make this good through, he carries it, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Indeed he displays his feet, rarely.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: See, see; he does the respective leer damnably well.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: The true idolater of your beauties, shall never pass their deities unadored: I rest your poor knight.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: See, now the oblique leer, or the Janus: he satisfies all, with that aspect, most nobly.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: And most terribly he comes off:a flourish. like your rodomantada.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: How like you this play, Anaides?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Good play; but 't is too rough, and boisterous.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I will second it with a stroke easier, wherein I will prove his language.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: This is filthy,a charge. and grave, now.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: O, 't is cool, and wary play. We must not disgrace our own comrade, too much.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Signora, ho tanto obligo per pefavore rescinto da lei; che verament dessidero con totto ill core, ● remuneraria in part: and sicurative signior a mea cara, chè infera sempre pronto à servirla, and honorarla. Bascio le mane de u● signoria.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: The Venetian Dop this.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Most unexpectedly excellent! The French goes down certain.

sp.speaker: Aso.
sp.l: As buckets are put down into a well;
Or as a schoolboy. —

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Truss up your simile, jackdaw, and observe.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Now the monsieur is moved.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Bo-peep.

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: O, most antique.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: The French quirk, this sir.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Heart, he will overrun her!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Madamoyselle, je voudroy que pouvoy monstrer mon affection, mais je suis tant mal heureuse, ci froid, ci laid, ci — je ne scay qui di dire — excuse moy, je suis tout vostre. a flourish.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O brave, and spirited! He's a right jovialist.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No, no: Amorphus gravity outweighs it.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: And yet your lady, or your feather would outweigh both.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: What's the prize, lady, at this better regard?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A face favourably simpering, and a fan waving.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: They have done doubtfully. Divide. Give the favourable face to the signior, and the light wave to the monsieur.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: You become the simper, well, lady.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And the wag, better.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Now, to our solemn address. Please the well-graced Philautia to relieve the lady sentinel; she hath stood long.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: With all my heart, come, guardian ▪ resign your place.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Monsieur, furnish yourself with what solemnity of ornament you think fit for this third weapon; at which you are to show all the cunning of stroke, your devotion can possibly devise.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Let me alone, sir. I'll sufficiently decipher your amorous solemnities. Crites, have patience. See, if I hit not all their practic observance, with which they lime twigs, to catch their fantastic ladybirds.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Ay, but you should do more charitably, to do it more openly; that they might discover themselves mocked in these monstrous affections.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: a charge. lackey, where's the tailor?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Here, sir.
See, they have their tailor, barber, perfumer, milliner, jeweller, feather-maker, all in common!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ay, this is pretty.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: they make themselves ready on the stage. here is a hair too much, take it off. Where are thy mullets?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is this pink of equal proportion to this cut, standing of this distance from it?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: That it is, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is it so, sir, you impudent poltroon? you slave, you list, you shreds, you. —

sp.speaker: Hed.
sp.p: Excellent. This was the best, yet.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, we must use our tailors thus. This is your true magnanimity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, go to: put on. We must bear with you, for the time's sake.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Is the perfume rich, in this jerkin?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Taste, smell; I assure you sir, pure benjamin, the only spirited scent, that ever awaked a Neapolitan nostril. You would wish yourself all nose, for the love on't. I frotted a jerkin, for a new-revenued gentleman, yielded me threescore crowns, but this morning, and the same titillation.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I savour no sampsuchine, in it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am a nullifidian, if there be not three thirds of a scruple more of sampsuchinum, in this confection, then ever I put in any. I'll tell you all the ingredients, sir.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: You shall be simple, to discover your simples.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Simple? why sir? what reck I to whom I discover? I have in it, musk, civet, amber, pheenicobalanus, the decoction of turmeric, sesame, nard, spikenard, calamus odoratus, stacte, opobalsamum, amomum, storax, laudanum, aspalathum, opponax, oenanthe. And what of all these now? what are you the better?
